title: Man admits causing death of schoolgirl, 10, in '47mph' hit-and-run crash
text:

A driver who admitted to causing the death of a 10-year-old schoolgirl in a hit-and-run crash faces a "substantial" jail sentence.

Connor Marsden, 24, was estimated to have been travelling at around 47mph - more than double the 20mph speed limit - when he hit Melissa Tate in Newcastle on the evening of September 25, the court heard.

The Mini Police volunteer's organs were donated and she saved the lives of five children after her tragic death.

Marsden, wearing a white sweater and appearing via video-link, gave no reaction as he pleaded guilty on Monday to causing Melissa's death by dangerous driving and a charge of failure to stop.

He also admitted causing death by driving while uninsured and while unlicensed.

(Image: handout)

(Image: Chronicle Live WS)

All of the charges relate to the crash in Kenton which led to the schoolgirl's death.

Mark Guiliani, prosecuting, told Newcastle Crown Court that Marsden was estimated to have been travelling at around 47mph on the 20mph road.

But Marsden's defence team argue that his speed was actually lower.

Judge Robert Adams warned Marsden that he faces a jail sentence.

(Image: Newcastle Chronicle)

The judge told him: "You must understand that these are serious matters you have admitted, and it's inevitable there will be a substantial custodial sentence."

Marsden, of Newcastle, will be sentenced on December 12.

In a statement after Melissa died last month, her parents, Michael Tate and Kimberley Wilson, said she had saved lives after her organs were donated.

Mr Tate said: “Melissa was a beautiful, smart, funny, cheeky and laid-back girl who had a heart of gold and not a bad bone in her body.

“She could brighten up anyone’s day and all she ever wanted to do is help people.

“Even after passing she still went on to help others by donating her organs.”

A fundraising campaign collected about £4,000 within days in support of her family.
description: Driver Connor Marsden, 24, was estimated to have been travelling more than twice the 20mph speed limit when 10-year-old Melissa Tate was fatally struck by his car in Newcastle, a court heard
